--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Joseph Reisinger <joeraii@c...> wrote:
> > Sadly, I didn't qualify for the Overseas Research Scholarship
(pretty much
> > the only recourse for PhD funding for non UK/EU students here), so
I'll be
> > returning to the US this autumn. I'm hoping to start a phd in
fall '05
> > (since i missed the app deadlines for this next year). Any
suggestions at
> > universities in the US doing interesting work? (UT already turned
me down
> > once ... I wonder if I should reapply?)
> 
> I think there was a thread about this before, but I don't remember.
I've
> met with both Rik Belew at UCSD and also Jordan Pollack who is at
> Brandeis. Both of them seem to be doing research that you would be
> interested in. Also there is a group in Florida I think, with Annie
Wu,
> but I'm not too familiar with her work.
> 
> > Also, I'm hoping to find some position next year (fall '04) as a
research
> > assistant or something ... any suggestions about places that might
hire
> > non-phds?
> 
> You might want to look into some corporate research labs. I know IBM
> Research hires even undergrad interns, and I'm pretty sure there are
a few
> other places around the country. As for academic labs, I'm not sure
what
> the policies are like. Ken might be able to add some insight.
> 

Yeah this issue has come up before and it's a tough issue in the US
since for whatever reason, schools in the US with this kind of
research are few and far between.  The places Joe mentioned are
definitely options, though I don't know that Annie Wu has done any
neuroevolution.  However, she is interested in encodings.  There is
also Darrell Whitley's group in Colorado.  He is the one who coined
the term "competing conventions."  I think it's definitely worth
reapplying to UT with your new credentials from the UK.  Risto's group
is unquestionably at the lead in the US in evolving neural networks.
There is also the possibility I will be a prof somewhere, which would
create another place, but I don't want to jinx myself!

ken
